item.description: Published: 1998 Tags: 1990s Canada Government Policy

item.title: A Flawed Encryption Policy
item.description: Published: April 1996 URL: https://search.proquest.com/docview/430685501/fulltext/2EA1B6B49BC74036PQ/1?accountid=14503 Tags: 1990s Clinton Crypto Wars Crypto Wars I Export Controls Terrorism Abstract: An editorial contends that the new White House proposal to keep high-powered encryption software out of the hands of foreign terrorists and criminals is needlessly restrictive and probably unworkable. The editorial says that the technology, which is legal in the US, is a good way for honest citizens to prevent crime and should be disseminated domestically and abroad.

item.title: A “Stumbling” US Encryption Policy
item.description: Authors: Madsen, Wayne Published: July 1997 URL: http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1361372397895486 Tags: 1990s Clinton Crypto Wars Crypto Wars I Export Controls Key Recovery Abstract: “Are those in opposition to the administration’s [encryption] policy prepared to sacrifice public safety in the interests of commercial gain?” Those words, uttered by Deputy Assistant Attorney General Robert Litt, would etch themselves in the minds of those who attended the 7 May 1977 House International Economic Policy and Trade hearing on “Encryption: Individual Rights vs National Security”.

item.title: Efforts to Ban Encryption in the 1990s
item.description: Authors: Center, Electronic Privacy Information Published: 1995 URL: https://www.epic.org/crypto/ban/ Tags: 1990s Crypto Wars Crypto Wars I Abstract: The Electronic Privacy Information Center (EPIC) focuses public attention on emerging civil liberties, privacy, First Amendment issues and works to promote the Public Voice in decisions concerning the future of the Internet.

item.title: Encryption and the First Amendment
item.description: Authors: Samoriski, Jan H. and Huffman, John L. and Trauth, Denise M. Published: September 1997 URL: https://doi.org/10.1080/10811689709368633 Tags: 1990s Amendment I Clinton Law Enforcement Abstract: Recently, only secret government agencies were concerned about cryptography. It now is an important matter for many individuals and businesses who use the Internet. That has led to an intense effort on the part of several governmental agencies to control cryptography. This article provides an explanation of the evolution of cryptography, a synopsis of the evolving cryptography debate, an examination of the different interests represented within the debate and a framework for analyzing the First Amendment issues that are involved.

item.title: Encryption Policy a Crowd Pleaser
item.description: Authors: Leiper, Jeff Published: November 1998 URL: http://search.proquest.com/docview/217686754?pq-origsite=summon Tags: 1990s Canada Abstract: At a meeting earlier this year by concerned industry players, the government was told that proposed restrictions were impractical because criminals had access to offshore encryption products. Further, the wait for a concrete policy was hurting business because companies were unsure of what they’d be allowed to sell. Shipping delays were costing money, officials from companies like kyberpass Corp.

item.title: Encryption: A 21st Century National Security Dilemma
item.description: Authors: Ackerman, Wystan M. Published: July 1998 URL: https://doi.org/10.1080/13600869855487 Tags: 1990s Clinton Export Controls Law Enforcement Abstract: As the 21st century approaches, encryption is presenting a national security dilemma in the US. While the use of strong encryption for computerized data is essential in protecting our nation, widespread, unregulated encryption poses serious problems on two levels: encryption could inhibit the government’s ability to enforce the law as well as gather foreign intelligence.

item.title: Executive Order 13026 - Administration of Export Controls on Encryption Products
item.description: Published: November 1996 Tags: 1990s Clinton Executive Order Export Controls

item.title: FAQ on the FCC CALEA Expansion
item.description: Published: 2015 URL: https://www.eff.org/issues/calea Tags: 1990s 2000s 2010s CALEA Abstract: The Communications Assistance for Law Enforcement Act (CALEA) of 1994 Congress passed the Communications Assistance for Law Enforcement Act (CALEA) in 1994, which forced telephone companies to redesign their network architectures to make it easier for law enforcement to wiretap digital telephone calls. In 2005, CALEA was expanded by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to include Internet service providers (ISPs) and VoIP services like Skype.

item.title: From Clipper Chip to Smartphones: Unlocking the Encryption Debate
item.description: Authors: Flatow, Ira URL: https://www.sciencefriday.com/segments/from-clipper-chip-to-smartphones-unlocking-the-encryption-debate/ Tags: 1990s 2010s Backdoors Clipper Chip Mobile Primer Abstract: In the ‘90s, the Clipper Chip was the big government encryption case. Two Science Friday guests involved in that early debate rejoin us to weigh in on the Apple argument.

item.title: Key Escrow
item.description: Published: April 1998 URL: https://epic.org/crypto/key_escrow/ Tags: 1990s Crypto Wars Crypto Wars I EPIC

item.title: Key Escrow from a Safe Distance: Looking Back at the Clipper Chip
item.description: Authors: Blaze, Matt Published: 2011 URL: http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?doid=2076732.2076777 Tags: 1990s 2010s Crypto Wars Crypto Wars I Abstract: In 1993, the US Government proposed a novel (and highly controversial) approach to cryptography, called key escrow. Key escrow cryptosystems used standard symmetric- and public- key ciphers, key management techniques and protocols, but with one added feature: a copy of the current session key, itself encrypted with a key known to the government, was sent at the beginning of every encrypted communication stream.

item.title: OECD Guidelines for Cryptography Policy
item.description: Published: March 1997 URL: https://www.oecd.org/sti/ieconomy/guidelinesforcryptographypolicy.htm Tags: 1990s OECD Abstract: Data and research on e-commerce including measuring the information economy, internet economy outlook, open internet, openness, key ICT indicators, digital economy policy papers., The Guidelines are primarily aimed at governments, in terms of the policy recommendations herein, but with anticipation that they will be widely read and followed by both the private and public sectors.

item.title: Standards Setting and Federal Information Policy: The Escrowed Encryption Standard (EES)
item.description: Authors: Gegner, Karen E. and Veeder, Stacy B. Published: January 1994 URL: http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0740624X94900183 Tags: 1990s Crypto Wars Crypto Wars I Encryption Standards Abstract: The controversial Escrowed Encryption Standard, recently adopted as a Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS), has polarized some stakeholders both within and outside government and has also raised disturbing questions about the role of Federal agencies in the standards-setting process. This article explores the relationship between standards and Federal information policy and examines the balance between national security and law enforcement concerns, on the one hand, and privacy rights and U.

item.title: The Risks of Key Recovery, Key Escrow, and Trusted Third-Party Encryption (Revised)
item.description: Authors: Abelson, H. and Anderson, R. and Bellovin, S.M. and Benaloh, J. and Blaze, M. and Diffie, W. and Gilmore, J. and Neumann, P.G. and Rivest, R.L. and Schiller, J.I. and Schneier, B. Published: 1998 URL: https://www.schneier.com/academic/archives/1997/04/the_risks_of_key_rec.html Tags: 1990s Crypto Wars Crypto Wars I Key Escrow Key Recovery Abstract: A variety of “key recovery,” “key escrow,” and “trusted third-party” encryption requirements have been suggested in recent years by government agencies seeking to conduct covert surveillance within the changing environments brought about by new technologies.

There was a need to establish a new arrangement to deal with risks to regional and international security and stability related to the spread … Continued

item.description: Published: February 2020 URL: https://www.wassenaar.org/the-wassenaar-arrangement/ Tags: 1990s Export Controls International / National Security Wassenar Arrangement Abstract: The Wassenaar Arrangement (WA), the first global multilateral arrangement on export controls for conventional weapons and sensitive dual-use goods and technologies, received final approval by 33 co-founding countries in July 1996 and began operations in September 1996. The WA was designed to promote transparency, exchange of views and information and greater responsibility in transfers of … Continued
